question: What is the purpose of using a microprocessor-based numeric relay in the circuit breaker?
ground_truth: The purpose of using a microprocessor-based numeric relay in the circuit breaker is to provide protection by avoiding any tampering.

question: What were the reasons for the contract termination between DLF and Leighton on 7 November 2020?
ground_truth: The contract was terminated by DLF on 7 November 2020 due to the disagreement between the parties regarding the pending works. DLF and the Engineer emphasized the importance of completing all pending works as a pre-requisite for awarding the Completion Certificate, while Leighton insisted that the pending works were minor and the Completion Certificate could be awarded without completing them.
contexts:
Arbitrator as alleged in its letter dated 07.07.2020”.

303. On 06 August 2020,165 the Employer stated that “At the outset, I categorically and vehemently deny contents of your Reply to Invocation Notice in entirety and nothing shall be deemed to be admitted for want of explicit denial except as may be specifically admitted hereto. It is fervently denied that no settlement has been reached between the Parties for reasons solely attributable to DLF Ltd. as alleged by you. In this regard, it is stated that no concrete proposals were put forward by you towards DLF's claims. It is also specifically denied that the Works as per the Contract Agreement was completed by Leighton as is being alleged in your Reply to Invocation Notice. It is further denied that DLF is in connivance with the Project Engineer appointed by it and is allegedly illegally withholding the Completion Certificate. It is reiterated that Leighton 163 SOC Annexure Volume 4 Page 1500 164 SOC Annexure Volume 4 Page 1506 165 SOC Annexure Volume 4 Page 1509

has itself admitted that till date the Project is far from completion and suffers from various defects. It is submitted that the Completion Certificate has not been issued by the Engineer for reasons solely attributable to Leighton as Leighton has been unable to complete the Project till date as per the terms of the Contract Agreement and owing to the same DLF has suffered huge additional expenses and incurred substantial loss and damages etc”.

304. On 07 November 2020,166 the Employer issued a notice for termination of the Contract under inter alia Clause 81 of the GCC.

305. On 18 November 2020,167 the Contractor stated that “I are in receipt of letter dated 7 November 2020, whereby you purport to terminate the captioned contract (‘Contract’). At the outset, I state that purported termination is wrongful and contrary to the terms of Contract. The contents of your letter under reply are denied and nothing therein is to be deemed to be admitted for want of specific traverse”. From the chronology listed above, I note that the Parties were in disagreement with respect to the pending works. Whilst DLF and the Engineer continuously highlighted the importance of closing out all pending works by Leighton as a pre-requisite to award CC, however Leighton remained adamant that the pending works are minor and the CC could be awarded without completing such pending works.

307.

Therefore, the works suffered delays and eventually the Contract was terminated by DLF on 7 November 2020.

6.7.2 Delay measurement

308. At the beginning of this window, the Project was in 10.6 months of critical delay.

309.

Since the Contract was terminated on 7 November 2020, I compare this date with the planned completion date of 3 September 2017.

310.

I calculate that 27.6 month168 of delay was between planned completion date and date of contract termination.

311.

Therefore, in summary the Project suffered 38.1 months of critical delay at the time of Contract termination.

6.7.3 Cause(s) of delay in the window

312. As noted above, IR submissions were prolonged in this window especially for T&C works and

then for snagging works at Tower A2 and C2.

313. Additionally, the general lack of progress by Leighton due to the onset of a potential dispute between the Parties regarding work completion and subsequent issue for Completion Certificate, possibly held up the works.

question: How do anchor bolts stabilize door frames when embedded at intervals?
ground_truth: Anchor bolts stabilize door frames by being fixed at specific intervals: one bolt is fixed at 200 mm from the top member, one at 200 mm from the floor, and a third in the center. This arrangement ensures that the vertical members of the door frame are securely held in place, providing stability and support.

welded. The hinge side vertica l outer frames shall be reinforced by galvanized M.S.

Tube of size 19 x 19 mm of wall t hickness l mm + 0.1 m m and a tie rod shall be provided at the bottom of the frame. The frame shall be fabricated in factory as per nomenclature of the item and directions of Engineer-in-Charge.

b) The frames are to be fixed in prepared openings in the walls. All civil work and tiling

shou ld be completed before the fixing of the frames. The frames are to be fixed directly on the plastered wall. In case t iling is to be done in the place the frames

are to be fitted, a SO mm strip should be left u ntiled at the loca tion w here the

frames are to be fitted. The frames are erected in the prepared opening such that the vertical members of the door frame are em bedded 50 mm in the floor. The

frame shall be fitted truly in plumb. A minimum of three anchor bolts or screws of

size 65/100 shall be used to fix each vertical member. One bolt shall be fixed at 200 mm from the top member and one bolt shall be fixed at 200 mm from the noor.

The third anchor bolt shall be fixed in the center. The top horizonta l member shall

be fixed using two 65/100 size anchor bolts or screws at a distance of 200 mm from both the corners.

1.1.8. STEEL WORK

STEEL WO RK IN BUILT UP SECTION (WELDED)

a) Stra ightening, shaping to form, cutting and assembling, shall be as far as applicable,

except that the words "riveted or bolted" shall be read as "welded" and holes shall only be used for the bolts used for temporary fastening as shown in drawings.

b) Welding shall generally be done by electric arc process as per IS 816 and IS 823. The electric arc method is usually adopted and is economical. Where electricity for

public is not available generators shall be arranged by the contractor at his own

cost unless otherwise specified. Gas welding shall only by resorted to using oxyacetylene flame with specific approval of the Engineer-in-charge. Gas welding

shall not be permitted for structural steel work Gas welding required heating o f the

members to be welded along with the welding rod and is likely to create temperature st resses in the welded members. Precautions shall t herefore be taken

to avoid distortion of the members due to these temperat ure stresses.

c) The work shall be done as shown in the shop drawings which should clearly indicate

various details of the joint to be welded, type of welds, shop and site welds as well

0086

to be done due to heights and difficult positions on scaffolding etc. apart from the

aspect of economy. The maximum dia of electrodes for welding work shall be as

per IS 814. Joint surfaces which are to be welded together shall be free from loose mill scale, rust, paint, grease or other foreign matter, which adversely affect the

qua lity of weld and workmanship.

e) Before welding is commenced, the members to be welded shall first be brought

together and firmly clamped or tack welded to be held in position. This temporary connection has to be strong enough to hold the parts accurately in place without

any disturbance. Tack welds located In places where final welds will be made later

shall conform to the fina l weld in quality and shall be cleaned off slag before fina l weld is made.

f) The specification shall be as described except that while erecting a welded structure

adequate means shall be employed for temporary fastening the members together and bracing the frame work until the joints are welded. Such means shall consists

of applying of erection bolts, tack welding or other positive devices imparting sufficient strength and stiffness to resist all temporary loads and lateral forces

including w ind. Owing to the small number of bolts ordinarily employed for joints which are to be welded, the temporary support of heavy girders carrying columns

shall be specially attended. Different members which shall be fillet welded, shall be brought into as close contact as possible. The ga p due to faulty workmanship or incorrect fit if any shall no t exceed.

question: How does the 'As-Planned vs. As-Built' method find key delays and their causes in 'The Camellias' project?
ground_truth: The 'As-Planned versus As-Built in Windows' method assesses the critical delay to Project completion by first identifying the route of the actual critical path, then assessing how much and when critical delay was incurred along the actual critical path, and finally linking the identified delay to specific causes on a retrospective basis through a detailed investigation of the available factual evidence.

Reference to Industry Standards

13.

In my assessment, I have relied on the procedure and techniques contemplated in the following internationally accepted industry standards which are generally used in the resolution of disputes related to delays in the construction projects world over.

(i)

Society of Construction Law (SCL) Delay and Disruption Protocol Second Edition 2017 (Annexure 9 of this Report), and

(ii) Association for the Advancement of Cost Engineering (AACE) International

Recommended Practice No. 29R-03 – Published in April 2011 (Forensic Schedule Analysis): (Annexure 10 of this Report).

14.

The SCL Protocol 2017 and AACE RP No. 29R-03 provide useful guidance on generally accepted principles of delay analysis that are not otherwise subject to the express provisions of the Contract.9 The relevant provisions of these standards are referred to in later sections of this Report.

1.7

Exclusions in our Expert Report

15.

The scope of my analysis is limited to providing an independent opinion from a technical analysis perspective. Whilst I refer to the relevant provisions of the Contract, this Report predominantly relates to opinions on completion issues and related matters.

16.

As part of the assessment, I have not provided the legal opinion or interpretation of the Contract on any of the issues covered herein.

1.8

Disclosure of Interests

17.

I confirm to the best of my knowledge that I have no relationships, current or prior, with the Parties in this Arbitration such that it may cause an actual or potential conflict of interest, or in any way influence the opinion I have provided in this Report.

9 Annexure XX: The SCL Protocol 2017 states in Introduction (Para A, Page 1): “....The object of the Protocol is to provide useful guidance on some of the common delay and disruption issues that arise on construction projects, where one party wishes to recover from the other an extension of time (EOT) and/or compensation for the additional time spent and the resources used to complete the project...”.

question: How do access and power delays affect S&T tests?
ground_truth: The delay in access to station buildings and yards, as well as the non-availability of stable and continuous AC power supply, affects the Testing and Commissioning activities of S&T Works. Block section testing activities can only commence on the availability of 230V AC through AT, and the delay in 230V AC supply leaves very little time for the STP-5 Contractor to complete the testing activities, affecting the progress of S&T works.
contexts:
�� Delay in access for Stations Buildings and Yard from CT P 1&2 Contractor. Several Buildings are under progress. Kindly note that there is a lead time to complete Signalling and Telecommunication works after Service Buildings are handed over to STP-5 Contractor by Civil Contractor. This lead time shall be typically 4 months for a Crossing Station and 6 months for a Junction Station. Till date only 03 station buildings viz. Saradhana, Haripur & Chandawal station buildings are handed over in CTP-2 section. For other remaining station buildings punch points issued by STP-5 contractor have to be closed by CTP-1&2 contractor.

Non-Availability of Service Buildings (Residential building, SDBD, MMU, IMSD, etc from CTP and TSS, SP, SSP, ATS and PP building from EMP-4) for completion of Telecom works. OFC and PIJF cable planning and laying is affected and installation of telecom equipment’s in these buildings.

Availability of 230V AC Power Supply is very crucial for Testing and Commissioning of S&T Systems. Earlier, EMP4 Contractor had provided the date of 25th Dec 18, then revised to Feb 2019 then June 2019 and now to September 2019 for availability of 230V AC Supply through AT at Stations and Block Sections. The delay of 230 V AC supply through EMP-4 Contractor leaves very less time to STP-5 Contractor to complete the testing activities and will be affecting the progress of S&T works as far as targets are concerned.

Non-availability of stable and continuous AC Power Supply is affecting the Testing and Commissioning activities of S&T Works. Block section testing activities can only be commenced on availability of 230V AC through AT.

Non availability of Loco is affecting Cab radio design and planning which in turn affects the overall

implementation of GSM-R system.

question: How does the FRTU use RBAC and Radius for user auth and failed logins, while meeting IEC 62351?
ground_truth: The FRTU supports secure access based on Role-based Access Control (RBAC), with the possibility to configure roles, in compliance with IEC 62351-8. Authentication is managed through a Radius server. It is possible to configure the FRTU to block authentication requests from an account after a number of failed login attempts, with the number of failed attempts and the time the account is blocked being configurable.

4.7 Sequence of Events (SOE) feature

To analyse the chronology or sequence of events occurring in the power system, time

tagging of data is required which shall be achieved through SOE feature of FRTU. The FRTU shall have an internal clock with the stability of lOOppm or better. Th e FRTU

time shall be set from time synchronization messages received from master station

using IEC 60870-5- 104 protocol. SOE time resolution shall be 10 ms or better

4.8 Control Outputs (16 DO capabilities In Acquisition module) The FRTU shall provide the capability for a master station to select and change the

state of digital output points. These control outputs shall be used to control power

system devices such as Circuit breakers, isolator, reset, relay disable/enable and other two-state devices, which shall be supported by the FRTU. A set of control

outputs shall be provided for each controllable device. On receipt of command from a master station using the select check-before-execute operate (SCBO) sequence, the

appropriate control output shall be operated for a preset time period which is

adjustable for each point from 0.1 to 2 seconds. Each control output shall consist of one set of potential free NO contact. The output contacts shall be rated for at least 0.2 Amp. at 24Vdc I 48 Vdc. These output contact shall be used to drive heavy duty relays. In case Control output module of FRTU does not provide potential free control

output contact of this rating, then separate control output relays sha ll be provided by the contractor. These relay coils shall be shunted with diodes to suppress inductive

transients associated with energizing and de-energizing of the relay coils & shall

conform to the relevant IEC requirements.

question: How did site issues and safety hazards, like transformer sparks, impact the Bada Pedestrianization timeline from Dec 2020 to Jul 2024?
ground_truth: The context does not provide specific information on how site issues and safety hazards, like transformer sparks, impacted the Bada Pedestrianization timeline from December 2020 to July 2024.

418. On 21 September 2022315 , the Contractor requested the Employer for tree removal from the site for smooth and safe execution.

419. As per the site MPR photographs, MLCP area was finally clear and available for starting of

work only on 25 November 2022.

420.

It is crucial to recognize that the Contractor and their workforce are entitled to a safe work environment. In the Contractor's letter dated 13 April 2023316, he highlighted that a transformer within the MLCP area premises was experiencing frequent sparks and fires, posing a serious safety risk to their workers. To prevent potential accidents, the Contractor requested that the Employer relocate the transformer outside the working premises.

421. The Contractor thus faced significant delays and hindrances in the progress of the Multi-Level Car Parking (MLCP) Project due to various obstacles, including an existing electrical substation, trees, and offices within the Project area. Despite repeated requests and reminders from January 2021 onwards, these issues were not resolved promptly, leading to idle resources and halted work. The Contractor emphasized the need for 100% site clearance to proceed with heavy machinery mobilization and construction activities. It wasn't until 3 August 2022 that the substation was dismantled, and the site was finally cleared for work on 25 November 2022, allowing the Project to proceed.

question: What specs and install practices ensure durable, well-fitted factory-painted C.I. rainwater pipes?
ground_truth: The specs and install practices for durable, well-fitted factory-painted C.I. rainwater pipes include: 1) Pipes conforming to IS 1230, being smooth, cylindrical, sound, and of uniform castings. 2) Pipes should be factory painted with a tar base composition both inside and outside. 3) Pipes should ring clearly when struck with a light hand hammer. 4) Pipes should be fixed perfectly vertical or to the lines as directed, with proper fitting of the spigot in the socket. 5) The annular space between the socket and spigot should be filled with spun yarn soaked in cement slurry and finished with cement mortar. 6) Pipes should be secured to walls with M.S. holder clamps, embedded in cement concrete blocks. 7) The joints should be kept wet for not less than 7 days. 8) Pipes should be embedded in masonry with a surrounding of 12 mm minimum thickness of mortar.

question: How did GSCDCL coordination issues and Nagar Nigam's pipeline work impact the Gwalior Smart City Project's timeline and costs from Dec 2020 to Jun 2024?
ground_truth: GSCDCL coordination issues and Nagar Nigam's pipeline work significantly impacted the Gwalior Smart City Project's timeline and costs. The contractor had to repeatedly halt and rebuild sections of the road due to interference from Nagar Nigam's pipeline work, leading to rework, increased costs, and requests for extensions of time. These disruptions, along with water supply line leaks, caused additional delays and required further rectification by the Contractor. The delay event involving the delay in handing over the possession of the site for Jhinsi Road commenced on 18 December 2020 and concluded on 27 June 2024.
contexts:
staff as required for the Project and had the meeting time to time on immediate start up activities such as Temporary office buildings finalization, Workman colony finalization, Topographical survey, GPR survey and the multi-level car parking coordinate finalization etc.” From this, we note that mobilization and planning work started in January month itself. According to the Monthly Progress Report from January 2021, the Contractor was actively conducting the Total Station Survey during that month. The GPR survey work for the MLCP was also underway. Additionally, minor dismantling work was progressing on Mahal Road.

It was observed that after the receival of drawing on 01 February 2023287, the Contractor when excavated the trial pit of around 650 mm, many Underground Utilities were found. Due to this the Employer instructed to hold the construction till further communication. In a meeting at Moti Mahal, it was decided to remove the duct from the scope of work and revert to surface relay instead of full road construction due to the increased number of utilities for Chatri Bazar Road, Idgah Road & Jhinsi Road.

388.

It was observed that the completed DBM work at Jhinsi Road, from Chainage 436 to Chainage 495, was damaged by Nagar Nigam (AMRUT Scheme), necessitating a complete rebuild of the road from Earthwork to DBM. The contractor requested Employer intervention to ensure Nagar Nigam completes their work before the road is finished to prevent further damage, additional costs, and delays.

389. The Contractor vide letter on 06 July 2023289 highlighted that the completed DBM work was damaged by Nagar Nigam (Amrut Scheme) at Jhinsi road LHS side from Ch.350 to Ch.740. The rectification was still pending due to which the footpath work and finishing works were pending at that time. A similar situation was observed from correspondence dated 20 July 2023290 for Ch.840 to Ch.1260 where the Nagar Nigam has damaged the completed road works for pipelaying. The Contractor in his letter requested the Employer to arrange NOC from the concerned department to take up the WMM & Bituminous work on priority.

390. The Contractor's submission of the Extension of Time (EOT) request, raised on 05 August 2023291, detailed several Delay Events in the accompanying write-up, explaining that,

“Jhinsi road

After receipt of drawing dt 11-4-23, we have started the road work and completed the DBM layer LHS side. But Nagar Nigam has damaged the completed the DBM layer for Pipeline work the same has been intimated to GSCDCL vide letter No. LTCD/SWI/MK/GSCDCL/2023-24/724 Dt: 13th Apr’23. Also, 400m stretch is still pending on RHS side due to pending Clearance from Nagar Nigam.”

391. As per the site order book, on 27 June 2024292, road was settled due to leakage of

existing water supply line of Amrut scheme. It was observed that the Contractor was requested to rectify this damage. Thus, it was observed that Contractor had to rework in this chainage and in turn delay was incurred.

392. Despite receiving drawings and proceeding with construction, the Contractor repeatedly had to halt and rebuild sections of the road due to interference from Nagar Nigam's pipeline work.

4.2.22. DE 22: Delay in handing over the possession of the Site for Remaining Roads

4.2.22.1. Introduction

395. We understand that land for the construction of the road work was to be handed over to the Contractor by the Employer. However, the belated provisioning of the land has caused delays to execution of the works.

restora tion of power after an outage w ithout need of manual intervention. All resta rts shall be reported to the connected master stations.

(h) Remote database download ing of FRTU from master station from SCADA/DMS control centre .

field devices.

question: How does the IGMS dual door seal ensure security if the outer door is opened?
ground_truth: The IGMS dual door seal ensures security by having a dual door sealing arrangement where even if the outer door is opened, the metering system and relays are not accessible. The inner door can only be opened after the outer door has been opened.

question: What steps are taken if design approvals delay the Rewari-Makarpura Signal & Telecom Works?
ground_truth: Weekly discussions with the Engineer on design status/issues are being done to finalize the designs quickly. Similar weekly reviews are being carried out on TMS issues/design approval. The design team has been strengthened with the induction of additional resources. Design review meetings are being held regularly with the Engineer at their office. Engineer verbal comments on Method Statement have been discussed, clarified, and incorporated accordingly to expedite the approval process.
contexts:
06-2020 vide letter No. STP5-GL-PMP-LTR-HIL-20/1188

Signalling



There has been no delay in the SIP submissions as comments provided by Engineer are being discussed and being incorporated on priority. Due care will be taken to ensure that dates provided in the Design review meeting are honoured.

 Weekly discussion with Engineer on design status / issues is being done to finalize the designs quickly.

Similar weekly review is being carried out on TMS issues / design approval.

 Mobilization of resources to the Sites where Access is available.

 Telecom design team discussing documents pre-submission and regular interaction are happening with

documentation are also approved and in advance stages now for remaining.

question: How does the Emden Formula for overheads affect project delay costs in construction?
ground_truth: The Emden Formula is used to calculate the head office overheads based on the delay analysis submitted by the Contractor. It estimates the lost contribution to the contractor's head office overheads due to project delays. The formula helps in determining the additional head office overhead costs incurred during the prolonged period of the project.
contexts:
or had to incur costs due to the operation and maintenance of the handed-over facilities and alleged that regular operation and maintenance are not within L&T's scope. The cost incurred under the operation and maintenance over the deployment of security guard, gardener, departmental workmen and other maintenance costs.

Further, the details of operation and maintenance costs are attached in Annexure H and the abstract of the same is presented in Table 21 below:

S. Nr. Expense Description Claim amount (INR) 1 Security Guard 11,51,330 2 Gardener 1,74,432 3 Departmental Workmen 4,50,447 4 Other Maintenance costs 1,82,800 Total Claim amount (INR) 19,59,009

 Table 21: Operation & Maintenance cost



Accordingly, the assessed claim amounts to INR 19,59,009 on account of operation and maintenance cost incurred by the Contractor.

Claim 08: Head office Overheads

Introduction

Head office overheads, also known as general and administrative (G&A) expenses, encompass the indirect costs incurred by a company's central operations. These expenses are vital for supporting the overall business activities and ensuring the smooth functioning of various departments within the organization. Understanding and managing head office overheads is crucial for maintaining financial health and operational efficiency.

In the construction industry, head office overheads typically include costs related to executive management, accounting, human resources, marketing, legal services, and other administrative functions that support the core project operations. Effective allocation and control of these overheads are essential for optimizing profitability and ensuring that resources are utilized efficiently across the enterprise.

The Contractor’s Head Office Overheads (HOO) contribute to the income of the business as a whole and are normally recovered/ derived from the individual projects undertaken.

Due to the prolongation of the Project duration without an increase in net income from the Project, the monthly income decreased, but on the other hand, the general running costs of the business (including Head Office costs) continued to be incurred in the same fashion till actual completion of the Project. This results in a direct loss to the Contractor.

Therefore, the claim for such recovery of Head Office costs has arisen, as the Contractor failed to recover this part of overheads which could have been reasonably expected during the prolongation period; and has been unable to recover such overheads because its resources have been tied up by delays beyond the control of the Contractor.

The major types of costs incurred by the Contractor from HO Overhead are as follows:

S. Nr. Construction Division Overheads 1 Employee Benefits Expense 2 Repairs Maintenance - Buildings (Elec. Installations and ICO) 3 Rent 4 Telephone Expenses - Others ICO 5 Power & Fuel 6 Professional fees 7 Travel - Inland Hotel Boarding & Lodging 8 Manpower Hire Charges 9 Cost of Software 10 Stationery & Printing 11 Bank Charges 12 Rates & Taxes 13 Repairs - other vehicles 14 Travel - Foreign Tickets 15 Advertising & Publicity 16 Other expenses A Total of Construction Division Overheads B Total of L&T Corporate Office's Overheads

Table 22: HO Overhead cost-heads

Further, the SCL Delay & Disruption Protocol, which is a well-recognized international standard/ guidance protocol for the assessment of EOT and associated claims in construction Projects, states the following:

“Head office overheads are the incidental costs of running the Contractor’s business as a whole and include indirect costs which cannot be directly allocated to production as opposed to direct costs which are the costs of production. Amongst other things, these overheads may include such things as rent, rates, directors’ salaries, pension fund contributions and auditors’ fees. In accountancy terms, head office overheads are generally referred to as administrative expenses, whereas the direct costs of production are referred to as costs of sales”.

This sets out a well-established basis of the claim, whereby the Contractor seeks the losses which it has suffered as a result of not being able to take on other projects owing to the delays (not attributable to itself) and subsequent prolongation of the Contract, that loss being the loss of its opportunity to defray its Head Office Overhead Charges over those other projects.

Claim amount and basis of calculation:

Based on the delay analysis submitted vide the Contractor’s latest EOT application, the Contractor is entitled to claim prolongation cost for 1186 days i.e. from the Project commencement date till the cut-off date of 31 March 2024.



The Contractor had calculated Head Office overheads based on the Emden Formula, as recommended in the Society of Construction Law, Delay and Disruption Protocol, 2nd Edition, February 2017 for the estimation of its lost contribution to its head office overheads.

In SCL Protocol 2017, the Emden Formula is defined

as:

The cost incurred towards head office overheads had been arrived by referring to the HQ overheads for all the financial years during the course of the Project.

The head office overheads between the FY 2020-21 to 2022-23 are provided by L&T as presented in the Table 22 below:

The Contractor’s entitlement to Extension of Time for delay events till 31 March 2024 is 1186 days. In this submission, the Contractor has claimed the Loss of Head Office overhead cost for the prolonged period of 1186 days. Accordingly, the Contractor reserves the right to claim further additional cost on account of loss of head office overhead in future.

Therefore, the assessed claim amounts to INR 12,47,48,377, representing the additional costs incurred due to head office overhead expenses during 640 days of excusable and compensable delays that were beyond the Contractor’s control, as detailed in the Contractor’s latest EOT Application.



Claim 09: Loss of Opportunity & Profit

Introduction

Should the project complete in the scheduled period, the Contractor would be closing the project with a profit margin as envisaged in the tender estimate. In the current scenario, its revenue target - which is dependent on the achieved progress of Works - is not met on a daily/ monthly level due to delays and disruption beyond the Contractor’s control, whereas their daily/monthly expenses were being incurred as planned; therefore, Contractor is bearing the loss of planned profit, which is differential % of the Planned Revenue and Planned Expense.

Loss of profit is a critical concern that can have far-reaching implications for contractors, developers, and stakeholders alike. This concept pertains to the financial losses incurred when projected profits from construction projects are not realized, typically due to delays, unforeseen expenses, or contractual disputes.

Loss of profit in the construction industry is not merely a reflection of missed financial targets; it encapsulates a broader spectrum of challenges that can disrupt project timelines, strain resources, and undermine business viability. Factors contributing to such losses can be multifaceted, ranging from inefficient project management and labour shortages to supply chain disruptions and adverse weather conditions. Additionally, legal disputes over Contract terms or delays in payments can further exacerbate the financial strain.
